ygData.subject: Re: FEEDBACK PLEASE re: [PROPOSAL] ARC file metadata body specification (Was "Heritrix ARC naming...")
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, I can t see anything wrong in the XML header (that doesn t prove anything though:) One could of course discuss these *) Does anybody ever use XML
ygData.rawEmail:
Return-Path: <kaisa.kaunonen@...>
X-Sender: kaisa.kaunonen@...
X-Apparently-To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
Received: (qmail 57016 invoked from network); 20 May 2004 11:31:43 -0000
Received: from unknown (66.218.66.166)
  by m21.grp.scd.yahoo.com with QMQP; 20 May 2004 11:31:43 -0000
Received: from unknown (HELO n19.grp.scd.yahoo.com) (66.218.66.74)
  by mta5.grp.scd.yahoo.com with SMTP; 20 May 2004 11:31:43 -0000
Received: from [66.218.67.171] by n19.grp.scd.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 20 May 2004 11:31:07 -0000
Date: Thu, 20 May 2004 11:31:06 -0000
To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
Message-ID: <c8i4tq+6mk6@...>
In-Reply-To: <40AB8CDA.8070409@...>
User-Agent: eGroups-EW/0.82
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Length: 16800
X-Mailer: Yahoo Groups Message Poster

From: "Kaisa Kaunonen" <kaisa.kaunonen@...>
Subject: Re: FEEDBACK PLEASE re: [PROPOSAL] ARC file metadata body specification (Was "Heritrix ARC naming...")
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=182123250
X-Yahoo-Profile: kaisa_kaunonen

Hi,
I can't see anything wrong in the XML header (that doesn't prove 
anything though:)

One could of course discuss these

*) Does anybody ever use XML descriptions separately from ARC files? 
If so there should be something telling which ARC this piece of XML 
describes, like
<rdf:Description rdf:about>the name of arc file</rdf:Description>

Could go into <dc:title> or some <dc:identifier> field.   

Same goes with date, shouldn't there be <dcterms:created> although 
file name contains the date.

*) What about file format, it's possible to create un/compressed arcs 
while crawling, should the XML say which type the result is. 

<dc:type>arc file version 1.1</dc:type>   
<dc:format >compressed binary file </dc:format>

or place both into <dc:type>
<dc:type>arc file version 1.1 compressed</dc:type>

*) <dcterms:audience>
If  Library of Congress authorizes Internet Archive to collect an 
archive, then in your notation IA is publisher and LC is audience.

I somehow think audience is something wider, it's the academic 
researchers who will use the archive. 

I'd like to have 
<dc:creator>Internet Archive</dc:creator>
<dc:publisher>LC</dc:publisher>

IA creates the arc files and LC makes them available to researchers?

Maybe LC has a fancy opinion on this.


kaisa




--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Mohr (@I... Archive)" 
<gojomo@a...> wrote:
> Michael's message from Monday, quoted below, covers an in-progress
> change we would very much like feedback on from the library 
community,
> and anyone with experience using Dublin Core elements/terms for
> born-digital materials.
> 
> We feel confident we can insert the extra XML into the ARC file 
header
> record, with negligible disruption to existing tools. Our questions 
are:
> have we chosen the right initial set of fields, and the right 
syntax/naming
> in both our use of DC and our own proposed namespace.
> 
> Any and all comments needed!
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> - Gordon @ IA
> 
> Michael Stack wrote:
> > This note is a follow on from a note sent a month ago by Gordon 
giving a 
> > heads-up and soliciting feedback on a new ARC file naming 
convention and 
> > of pending changes to the ARC file metadata record.
> > 
> > The change to the heritrix naming of ARCs has been completed and 
> > committed to the code base.  The format is now:
> > 
> > <OPERATOR SPECIFIED> '-' <12 DIGIT TIMESTAMP> '-' <SERIAL NO.> '-
' <FQDN 
> > HOSTNAME> '.arc' | '.gz'
> > 
> > ... where <OPERATOR SPECIFIED> is any operator specified text, 
<SERIAL 
> > NO> is a zero-padded 5 digit number and <FQDN HOSTNAME> is the 
> > fully-qualified domainname on which the crawl was run.
> > 
> > Here is an example: UKGOV-200403221010-00004-
debord.archive.org.arc.gz
> > 
> > The rest of this note is a more formal description of the HEADER 
section 
> > of Gordon's note describing the changes we intend to make to the 
ARC 
> > record metadata header and metadata body.  Again, comments are 
invited.
> > 
> > ARC FILE METADATA RECORD -- i.e. the first record of an ARC -- 
PROPOSED 
> > CHANGES
> > 
> > 1. If an ARC file metadata record has extra information in its 
body, the 
> > second '<reserved>' field of the second line of version 1 ARC 
files will 
> > be changed from '0' to '1'.  Previously, in version 1, ARC 
metadata 
> > records had zero-length bodies [See #1 for description of version 
1 ARC 
> > files].
> > 2. If present, the ARC file metadata record body will contain at 
least 
> > the following fields.  Later revisions of may add other fields:
> > 
> > 2a.  Software and software version used creating the ARC file.  
The 
> > value of this field is not overrideable by an operator.  Example: 
> > 'heritrix 0.7.1 http://crawler.archive.org'.
> > 2b. The IP of the host that created the ARC file.  The value of 
this 
> > field is not overrideable by an operator.  Example: '103.1.0.3'.
> > 2c. The hostname of the host that created the ARC file.  The 
value of 
> > this field is not overrideable by an operator.  Example 
> > 'debord.archive.org'.
> > 2d. Contact name of the crawl operator.   The operator will be 
able to 
> > set this value upon job creation.  Default value is 'admin'. 2e. 
The 
> > http-header 'user-agent' field from the crawl-job order file. 
This field 
> > is recorded here in the metadata only until the day ARCs record 
the HTTP 
> > request made.  Example: 'os-heritrix/0.7.0 
(+http://localhost.localdomain)'.
> > 2f. The http-header 'from' from the crawl-job order file.  This 
field is 
> > recorded here in the metadata only until the day ARCs record the 
HTTP 
> > request made.  Example: 'webmaster@l...'.
> > 2g. The 'description' from the crawl-job order file.  
Example: 'Heritrix 
> > integrated selftest'.
> > 2h. Robots obeyed.  Copied from crawl-job order file.  
Example: 'true'.
> > 2i. Organization on whose behalf the operator is running the 
crawl.  
> > Example 'Internet Archive'.
> > 2j. The 'name' from the crawl-job order file.  
Example: 'Selftest' or 
> > 'UKGOV-April2004'.
> > 2k. The recipient of the crawl ARC resource if known.  
Example: 'Library 
> > of Congress'.
> > 
> > 3. The above listed fields will be written into the ARC file 
metadata 
> > body as validatable XML.
> > 4. The XML Schema used to validate will be in the main qualified 
Dublin 
> > Core [#2] with mixed in Internet Archive elements and 
refinements.  The 
> > DC elements with qualifiers will be used to describe the ARC 
resource 
> > itself.  The Internet Archive elements will be used to record 
> > information about the context in which the crawler wrote the ARC 
and 
> > Internet Archive element-qualifiers will be used refining DC 
elements.
> > 5.  Here are example XML instances to match the XML schema as yet 
> > undefined outlined in 4. above featuring the fields listed in 2. 
above.
> > 
> > 5.1 Selftest
> > 
> > Given:
> > 
> > Operator="stack at archive dot org"
> > Organization="Internet Archive"
> > Crawl-Job Description="Heritrix integrated selftest."
> > Crawl-Job Name="Selftest"
> > Recipient of arc="Selftest analysis"
> > 
> > The XML instance will look like:
> > 
> > <arcmetadata xmlns="http://archive.org/arc/meta/1.0/"
> >  xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
> >  xsi:schemaLocation="http://archive.org/arc/meta/1.0 
> > http://archive.org/arc/meta/1.0/schema.xsd"
> >  <!--iac namespace done for sake of clarity demarking naming in 
the 
> > below.-->
> >  xmlns:iac="http://archive.org/arc/meta/1.0/"
> >  xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"
> >  xmlns:dcterms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/">
> > 
> > <dc:publisher>Internet Archive</dc:publisher>
> > <dc:description>Heritrix integrated selftest</dc:description>
> > <dcterms:audience>Selftest analysis</dcterms:audience>
> > <dcterms:isPartOf 
xsi:type="dcterms:Collection">Selftest</dcterms:isPartOf>
> > <dc:creator xsi:type="iac:operator">stack at archive 
org</dc:creator>
> > <dc:creator xsi:type="iac:host-ip">127.0.0.1</dc:creator>
> > <dc:creator 
xsi:type="iac:hostname">localhost.localdomain</dc:creator>
> > <dc:creator xsi:type="iac:software">Heritrix 0.7.1 
> > http://crawler.archive.org</dc:creator>
> > <iac:robots-honored>true</iac:robots-honored>
> > <iac:http-header-from>stack@c...</iac:iac:http-header-from>
> > <iac:http-header-user-agent>os-heritrix/0.7.0 
> > (+http://localhost.localdomain)
> >     </iac:http-header-user-agent>
> > <!--Boilerplate-->
> > <dc:type>ARC file version 1.1</dc:type>
> > <dcterms:conformsTo
> > 
xsi:type="dcterms:URI">http://www.archive.org/web/researcher/ArcFileFo
rmat.php</dcterms:conformsTo>
> > </arcmetadata>
> > 
> > 5.2 Library of Congress crawl run by Internet Archive
> > 
> > Given:
> > 
> > Operator="stack at archive dot org"
> > Organization="Internet Archive"
> > Crawl-Job Description="May 2004 Election Crawl."
> > Crawl-Job Name="Election2004-May"
> > Recipient of arc="Library of Congress"
> > 
> > The XML instance will look like:
> > 
> > <arcmetadata xmlns="http://archive.org/arc/meta/1.0/"
> >  xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
> >  xsi:schemaLocation="http://archive.org/arc/meta/1.0 
> > http://archive.org/arc/meta/1.0/schema.xsd"
> >  <!--iac namespace done for sake of clarity demarking naming in 
the 
> > below.-->
> >  xmlns:iac="http://archive.org/arc/meta/1.0/"
> >  xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"
> >  xmlns:dcterms="http://purl.org/dc/terms/">
> > 
> > <dc:publisher>Internet Archive</dc:publisher>
> > <dc:description>May 2004 Election Crawl</dc:description>
> > <dcterms:audience>Library of Congress</dcterms:audience>
> > <dcterms:isPartOf 
> > xsi:type="dcterms:Collection">Election2004-May</dcterms:isPartOf>
> > <dc:creator xsi:type="iac:operator">stack at archive 
org</dc:creator>
> > <dc:creator xsi:type="iac:host-ip">123.1.2.3</dc:creator>
> > <dc:creator 
xsi:type="iac:hostname">crawl08.archive.org</dc:creator>
> > <dc:creator xsi:type="iac:software">Heritrix 0.7.1 
> > http://crawler.archive.org</dc:creator>
> > <iac:robots-honored>false</iac:robots-honored>
> > <iac:http-header-from>stack@c...</iac:iac:http-header-from>
> > <iac:http-header-user-agent>os-heritrix/0.7.0 
> > (+http://localhost.localdomain)
> >     </iac:http-header-user-agent>
> > <!--Boilerplate-->
> > <dc:type>ARC file version 1.1</dc:type>
> > <dcterms:conformsTo
> > 
xsi:type="dcterms:URI">http://www.archive.org/web/researcher/ArcFileFo
rmat.php</dcterms:conformsTo>
> > </arcmetadata>
> > 
> > 6. The IA schema of qualifiers and elements will be available at 
> > http://archive.org/arc/meta/1.0 (This URL is subject to change).  
The DC 
> > schema is available at [#3].
> > 7. On the notion of adding the complete crawl-job order file to 
the ARC, 
> > that was made into an RFE at [#4].
> > 
> > #1. ARC file formal description: 
> > http://www.archive.org/web/researcher/ArcFileFormat.php.
> > #2. Dublic Core Metadata Initiative (DCMI): http://dublincore.org
> > #3. Notes on XML Schema for Qualified DC: 
> > http://dublincore.org/schemas/xmls/qdc/2003/04/02/notes/
> > #4. Adding crawl-job order file to arcs: 
> > http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?
func=detail&aid=955562&group_id=73833&atid=539102
> > 
> > Yours,
> > St.Ack
> > 
> > --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Mohr (Internet 
Archive)" 
> > <gojomo@a...> wrote:
> >  > Thanks for the comments, everyone. Some of these are good ideas
> >  > that we won't get to for 1.0, but will keep on the docket for
> >  > later.
> >  >
> >  > kaisa_kaunonen wrote:
> >  > > Hi all,
> >  > >
> >  > > good ideas you have, here are a couple of comments =>
> >  > >
> >  > > It's not possible to tell from file names which job each arc 
file
> >  > > comes from?
> >  >
> >  > Not automatically: it depends on the operator choosing an ARC 
name
> >  > prefix that correlates with the Heritrix job name.
> >  >
> >  > I don't think we want to force these to be the same. The job
> >  > names get a formulaic (timestamp) expansion for UI convenience
> >  > and uniqueness within the application's domain. However, the
> >  > naming needs for long-term ARC file archival may be different 
and
> >  > thus can be chosen in separate ARC name options.
> >  >
> >  > Job names should definitely go into the in-ARC header record;
> >  > I'll make that a clear part of the arc-header spec.
> >  >
> >  > > During harvesting every job has its own directory but in the 
end one
> >  > > may place all arcs into a bigger pool for further processing.
> >  > >
> >  > > Would a series number be unique only inside a job so you 
could have
> >  > > files
> >  > >
> >  > > name - 00001 - timestamp1 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > > name - 00001 - timestamp2 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > > name - 00001-  timestamp3 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > > name - 00001 - timestamp4 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > >
> >  > > produced by four different jobs. I somehow think a running 
series
> >  > > number in an archive implies that no two files in an archive 
have
> >  > > identical s-numbers (even if their timestamps differ)
> >  >
> >  > The serial numbers are strictly within a single crawl/job for 
now.
> >  > Attempting uniqueness over a larger domain would require other
> >  > coordination between jobs, software runs, software installs, 
etc.
> >  >
> >  > It is currently up to the operator to vary the prefix-names on
> >  > subsequent runs in such a situation. If they don't, the above
> >  > is possible, which is a potential source of confusion with both
> >  > the grouping you show, and when you consider that the default
> >  > sort order of the ARCs of separate crawls will be...
> >  >
> >  > name - 00001 - timestamp1 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > name - 00001 - timestamp3 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > name - 00001-  timestamp5 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > name - 00001 - timestamp7 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > name - 00002 - timestamp2 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > name - 00002 - timestamp4 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > name - 00002-  timestamp6 - IP.arc.gz
> >  > name - 00002 - timestamp8 - IP.arc.gz
> >  >
> >  > Because of this, we've decided to keep the timestamp and 
serial-number
> >  > values in the current code's order, timestamp first, then 
serial-number,
> >  > so that within a given 'name', the lexicographic sort order 
will always
> >  > match the time-sort order.
> >  >
> >  > > S-number makes file names more unique but it's not very 
informative.
> >  >
> >  > We find the serial numbers helpful as a way to highlight a
> >  > particular ARC as the container of a resource of interest.
> >  > For example, "you can grep for the weird server response in ARC
> >  > #27". The timestamps are somewhat more difficult to use as
> >  > casual pointers.
> >  >
> >  > > Would it be possible to use job name instead
> >  > >
> >  > > OperatorGivenName - Jobname - Timestamp - IP.arc.gz for 
example =>
> >  > >
> >  > > finland - photoarchives - timestamp - IP.arc.gz
> >  > >
> >  > > Slight problem of course that job names have variable 
lengths unlike
> >  > > s-numbers.
> >  >
> >  > I suspect many operators will want to make their ARC prefixes
> >  > and jobnames match, but for the reasons listed above, I'd
> >  > rather not enforce that relationship in software.
> >  >
> >  > Some other ideas for the future:
> >  >   - an operator could be offered a easy way (checkbox?) to
> >  >     make the ARC prefix conform to the job name
> >  >   - an operator could be warned if a arc-prefix was used
> >  >     in a known previous crawl, and offered a suggested
> >  >     revision
> >  >   - the crawler could consult an external inventory process
> >  >     somewhere to verify that a proposed crawl name and
> >  >     ARC prefix are unique
> >  >
> >  > Andrew Boyko wrote:
> >  > # The ARC naming proposal sounds good to me.  The only thing I 
might
> >  > # ponder is the idea of a separate identifier, for the 
instance of a
> >  > # repeated crawl.   Obviously the operator could just add a 
suffix to the
> >  > # 'operator-given-name', and the timestamp is a clear key to 
regularly
> >  > # repeated crawls (monthly or weekly), so this isn't a big 
deal.  
> > Even so,
> >  > # it's still compelling to have the tool auto-generate a 
sequence number
> >  > # whenever a operator-given-name is reused within an instance 
of the 
> > tool.
> >  > #  Two or three digits would presumably more than cover it.
> >  > #
> >  > # So in the example of repeated Congress crawls (to choose an 
example at
> >  > # random :), assuming the same instance of the tool is used 
for each, the
> >  > # seventh ARC for the fifth instance of the crawl would be
> >  > #    CONGRESS005-00007-20040420133907-FG71E2B.arc.gz
> >  > # where the 005 is automatically assigned by the crawler based 
on the
> >  > # prior instances it knows of, and of course defaults to 001 
for any new
> >  > # crawl name.
> >  >
> >  > We've been relying on operator diligence to do this, and 
picking 
> > date-related
> >  > names -- things like CONGRESS0312 (dec 2003), CONGRESS0401 
(jan 
> > 2004), etc.
> >  >
> >  > I agree automating this would be a big operator convenience 
For the 
> > current
> >  > update, though, we'll leave this as a manual practice rather 
than rush in
> >  > an automated system that might be constraining.
> >  >
> >  > # As far as the new header block, why not add the entire crawl 
order and
> >  > # seed list?  A couple K added to a 100MB file shouldn't worry 
anyone.
> >  >
> >  > Excellent point. It might also be achieved as a special record
> >  > past the header; perhaps even as a crawler self-fetch, like...
> >  >
> >  >    http://127.0.0.1:8080/currentcrawl/order.xml
> >  >
> >  > It might be sufficient to do this only for the first ARC, or 
otherwise
> >  > include this info by reference where preferred by the operator.
> >  >
> >  > - Gordon @ IA
> > 
> > 
> > 
> >  
> > Yahoo! Groups Links
> > 
> > 
> > 
> >  
> >
